page.title: Simple and Possessed Nominal Phrases
page.introduction:
Nominal phrases can be very complex, so they will be divided into four sections in this starter kit. This section concentrates on those with common nouns as the lexical head. We will consider modification by articles, demonstratives, quantifiers and degree words, adjective phrases, and possessors. Nominal phrases headed by pronouns, proper names, demonstratives, and quantifiers are handled in
Pronouns and Proper Names. The possibility of modification by pre/post-positional phrases is added in
Pre/Post-positional Phrases and modification by relative clauses is added in
Relative Clauses.

Because there are so many positions needed for distinct sets of modifiers, we will use the expanded DP (determiner phrase) structure, rather than the simpler NP phrase structure. These more complex tree structures will be built step-by-step from your answers to the questions here. You simply need to be aware that when you look at the tree structures generated, nominal phrases will have DPs on top of the NPs. A simple English example is given here:
DP
______|_______
Deg D'
just ______|______
Dem NP
those |
N'
_____|______
AdjP N'
| ____|____
Adj AdjP N'
fine | |
Adj N
young men
It may be difficult to understand the need for the change in English, because articles, demonstratives and possessors are mutually exclusive, but in many languages all three can occur in a single nominal phrase. (Click here to see more on the DP hypothesis.)

form.introduction: Many languages require agreement between at least some of the modifiers and the head noun. While English only has number agreement, in other languages this agreement may also include animacy, class, or gender. The grammar rules generated by this starter kit include the constraints for full agreement, but if your language only has partial or no agreement, you simply will not add those features to your lexical items. In that case, the constraints will only apply vacuously. Based on your answers below about the agreement system in your language, you will be instructed to add the appropriate features in the sections that follow.

radioGroup.prompt: Think about the various modifiers that can be included in a nominal phrase, as in the tree structure above. Does your language have any marking on articles, demonstratives, adjectives, etc. to show number agreement with the head noun?
radioGroup.radio: No, there is no agreement, but number marking comes from the number or quantifier
Yes, like English, the various nominal modifiers may/must agree in number with the head noun

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have any additional features which may or must be marked on modifiers so that they agree with the head noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they may/must agree in animacy
Yes, they may/must agree in class number
Yes, they may/must agree in gender

form.introduction:
Besides agreement, nouns and their modifiers may be marked for case. Therefore, we need to know what case system, if any, your language uses.
The most common case system is nominative-accusative. This is the system English has, though only pronouns are marked for case in English. In a nominative-accusative system, subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are in nominative case, while direct objects are accusative case. Possessors are genitive case. The nominative pronouns in English are: I, we, you, he, she, they. The accusative pronouns are: me, us, you, him, her, them. The genitive pronouns include: my, mine, our, ours, your, yours, his, her, hers, their, theirs. Therefore, we say They hit him and not Them hit he.
In an ergative-absolutive case system, subjects of transitive verbs are in the ergative case, while objects of transitive verbs and subjects of intransitive verbs are in the absolutive case. The case of possessors is not set cross-linguistically, so if your language has an ergative-absolutive system, you will be asked about the case of possessors in that section.
Some languages are even more complex in that they normally have a nominative-accusative system but under some conditions the case system switches to ergative-absolutive. This is called "split ergativity". In this starter kit, the best we can do for these languages is to add all the rules allowing both case systems. Afterward, the specific constraints needed for your language can be added to the rules.

radioGroup.prompt: Based on the description of the case systems above, which one is correct for your language? Be sure to think about pronouns as well as nouns in considering your answer.
radioGroup.radio: None: the exact same set of pronouns may be used in any position in the sentence and there is no marking on nouns or on any noun modifiers based on their position in the sentence
Nominative-Accusative: like English, subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are the same, but objects of transitive verbs are different
Ergative-Absolutive: subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs are the same, but subjects of transitive verbs are different
Split Ergativity: the language has a Nominative-Accusative system normally, but the Ergative-Absolutive system is used under certain conditions.
